title: Susanna Reid defends Naga Munchetty over BBC 'flip-flop' on complaint
text:
‘All its stars must be confused,’ Reid said of the BBC Breakfast presenters. ‘What exactly can they say?’ (Picture: Rex / BBC)

They may be on competing morning TV shows, but Susanna Reid has spoken out in defence of Naga Munchetty following the furore over a viewer complaint about comments she made on BBC Breakfast about Donald Trump.

The BBC this week overturned a decision to partially uphold the complaint against Munchetty, which came after she spoke out on air against Trump’s controversial July tweet in which he told four female congresswomen to ‘go back and help fix the totally broken and crime-infested places from which they came’.

The BBC’s original decision, which initially found that Munchetty had breached editorial guidelines, sparked an outcry as figures including Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Channel 4 News presenter Krishnan Guru-Murthy and Sir Lenny Henry all criticised the BBC.

Munchetty was back on the BBC Breakfast sofa yesterday (3 October) for the first time since the decision was overturned, and she’s now received further public backing from Good Morning Britain host Reid.

Writing for the Mail Online, Reid, who affirmed that she was ‘a proud ex-BBC employee’, said the BBC had ‘flip-flopped’ over their handling of the case and said that it ‘doesn’t look good’ for the corporation.

‘All its stars must be confused. What exactly can they say?’ Reid wrote.

‘At ITV, we’re bound by the same broadcasting impartiality rules.

Reid presented BBC Breakfast for 10 years before switching to ITV (Picture: Ken McKay/ITV/REX)

‘I would never want anyone to be able to tell which way I vote, but we’re encouraged to share our opinions and experiences and viewers love it.’

Reid said that that openness to expressing opinions on the air was ‘especially important when, like Naga, a presenter has a personal story that’s truly relevant to the news.

‘Otherwise, what are we there for?’

Reid’s GMB co-host Piers Morgan also publicly defended Munchetty this week, before slamming the ‘sinister’ Editorial Standards department at the BBC.
